sense.name: a physical point of access, e.g., door, opening
sense.commentary: ENTRANCE[+structure][+physical][+access] Note: refers to a region or structure to pass through.
sense.examples: That entrance to the freeway was closed this morning during rush hour. Guards stood at the entrance of the palace. The back entrance to the building is locked after 6 PM.

sense.name: the state of admission to something
sense.commentary: ENTRANCE[+state][+admission] Note: often used in phrase 'gain entrance'
sense.examples: Many nations are uneasy about their entrance into the nuclear club. John passed his entrance exams to medical school. The burglar attempted to gain entrance through the kitchen window. (he admitted himself) About fifty people gained entrance to the rock concert without tickets.

sense.name: the act of entering
sense.commentary: ENTRANCE[+action][+movement][+appearance] Note: implies physically appearing somewhere
sense.examples: Sally loves to make a grand entrance at a party. His final entrance in the play is during the first scene of Act 3. Passengers were concerned at the entrance of two bomb-sniffing dogs onto the plane.

sense.name: the temporal beginning of a musical work
sense.examples: The tenor missed his entrance on the fifth measure. It's a difficult pianissimo violin entrance.
